questions.text: Which of the following is an 'Anti-infective' vitamin?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A is required for the maintenance of epithelial functions, creating an effective barrier against pathogens; hence, it is called as an anti-infective vitamin. So, vitamin A deficiency can lead to changes in the epithelia of all mucosal surfaces, leading to increased chances of infections.

Vitamin E (Tocopherol) helps is an anti-oxidant. Deficiency manifests as skin changes and hair loss. 

Vitamin D maintains calcium and phosphorus homeostasis. Deficiency can lead to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

Vitamin C helps in the formation of connective tissues and collagen in the skin, bone, and blood vessels. Deficiency leads to their fragility and causes scurvy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old unvaccinated girl is brought to the OPD with high-grade fever and maculopapular rashes for 2 days. On examination, she has blue-white spots on her buccal mucosa as shown in the image attached below. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The girl is suffering from measles. It is associated with vitamin A deficiency.

Vitamin A deficiency is associated with an increased risk of infection and increased mortality with a variety of infectious diseases particularly measles. Hence, vitamin A therapy is indicated in all patients with measles.

The main functions of vitamin A are as follows:

  • Maintenance of vision, especially night vision
  • Maintenance of epithelial tissues
  • Differentiation of various tissues, particularly during reproduction and gestation, by regulating gene expression.

Features of vitamin A deficiency:

  • Eyes: Defective dark adaptation is a characteristic early clinical feature, resulting in night blindness (earliest manifestation). This can further progress to xerophthalmia, Bitot's spots, conjunctivitis, or keratomalacia, leading to blindness.
  • Poor overall growth, anaemia
  • Diarrhoea, susceptibility to infections
  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Keratinization of mucous membranes and skin (hyperkeratosis)

questions.text: A young girl of class 4 complains of a burning sensation in the eye. Clinical examination of eyes reveals the finding shown below. What could be the mechanism for the development of such lesions?

choices.text: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is showing Bitot spots, which occur due to keratinization of the conjunctival epithelium. Bitot spots are triangular, frequently bilateral, and present on the bulbar conjunctiva.

Normally, bulbar conjunctiva is a stratified, columnar, non-keratinized epithelium. In vitamin A deficiency, there is squamous metaplasia of the conjunctival epithelium and tangles of keratin admixed with gas-forming bacteria producing a dry, scaly patch with a foamy appearance called Bitot spots.

Option A: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva is termed conjunctival concretions, which usually occurs over the palpebral conjunctiva, in chronic inflammatory conditions of the eye.

Option B: Scarring of the conjunctiva is seen in chlamydial infection of the eye.

Option C: Excessive growth of conjunctival tissue is seen in the pterygium of the eye.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with complaints of dry, itchy eyes and night blindness had the following ophthalmic finding as given in the image. What is the stage of vitamin A deficiency as per WHO classification?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a corneal ulcer occupying <1/3rd of the cornea under a slit lamp with a fluorescein stain. This corresponds to stage X3A of vitamin A deficiency.

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of headache, desquamation of the skin, and bone pain. Pathological examination revealed lysosomal rupture within the cells, prompting a suspicion of hypervitaminosis A. Which of the following statement is false about the principle vitamin that is excess in the given condition?
  1. All-trans retinoic acid is the most bioactive form of vitamin A.
  2. Protein Energy Malnutrition (PEM) can cause vitamin A deficiency.
  3. Excess vitamin A causes hyperostosis.
  4. Raised Intracranial Pressure (ICP) can be seen in hypervitaminosis but not deficiency of vitamin A.
  5. 11-trans retinal is required for vision.
questions.solution:
Both hypervitaminosis A and deficiency of vitamin A cause raised intracranial pressure (ICP) (not just hypervitaminosis A). 11-cis retinal(not trans) is required for vision.

Hypervitaminosis A causes headache, vomiting, desquamation of the skin, and hyperostosis of long bones. Rupture of lysosomes in the cells is the pathological feature of hypervitaminosis A.

All-trans retinoic acid is the most bioactive form of vitamin A, and it is required for cell differentiation and the regulation of transcription. On the other hand, 11-cis retinal is required for vision. Protein-energy malnutrition can cause vitamin A deficiency because of the impaired synthesis of retinol-binding protein (RBP).

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: Your best friend is recently worried that she has a lot of hair fall. Which of the following vitamin capsules if added to her diet can help prevent free radical injury and thus be beneficial for her??
questions.solution:
Vitamin E/ Tocopherol is a potent antioxidant and is helpful in preventing hair fall. It promotes hair growth and prevents hair roots from getting damaged by free radical injury.

Alpha-tocopherol is the active component of vitamin E and it is mainly located within cell membranes, preventing lipid peroxidation and the formation of free radicals.

Deficiency of this can also lead to neurological defects, hemolysis, and posterior column defect.

Treatment includes vitamin E supplementation (25–50 units/day for a week).

Note:

The other vitamins having antioxidant properties are vitamins A, C, and E (vitamin E is the most important).

The other vitamin beneficial in the treatment of hair fall is biotin.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 6-month-old child with concerns about not gaining weight and height.  On examination, stunted growth, craniotabes, frontal bossing, and craniosynostosis are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Craniotabes (soft skull), frontal bossing, stunted growth, and craniosynostosis are clinical features of rickets.

General features include failure to thrive, listlessness, protruding abdomen, proximal muscle weakness, and fractures.

Head to toe-examination would include the following features:

Head examination would include craniotabes, frontal bossing, delayed fontanel closure, delayed dentition, and craniosynostosis.

Chest examination would reveal rachitic rosary, Harrison's sulcus, and repeated respiratory infections and atelectasis.

Spinal deformities could include kyphosis, scoliosis, lordosis.

Limb examination and extremities may show windswept deformity, anterior bowing of tibia, coxa vara, and enlargement of wrists and ankles. Bowings of legs (genu varum) or knock knees (genu valgum) may be noted. These changes can be seen only in children of the weight-bearing age group/ toddlers.

The image below shows the rachitic rosary:

 

The image below shows craniotabes:

questions.text: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the above X-ray image shows fraying and cupping of the metaphysis, suggestive of rickets.

Radiological features in rickets:

  • Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate)
  • Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis)
  • Splaying at metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends)
  • Generalized rarefaction

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this deformity?
questions.solution:
Windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg) is seen in rickets. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but characteristically seen in rickets.

Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

Your school friend brings his 5-year-old son to your OPD with small swellings on the chest that he had felt while giving the child a bath. On examination, you note swellings at the costochondral junctions. Which of the following conditions would be your differentials to this clinical presentation?

questions.text: A 22-month-old girl presents with failure to thrive and delayed achievement of motor milestones. On examination, she seems irritable and is noted to have bowed legs, thick wrists, and dental caries. Which of the following is not a radiographic sign of this condition?

choices.text: Increase in the width of the growth plate

questions.solution:
The child is suffering from rickets. Subperiosteal hemorrhage is not a radiographic sign of rickets. On the contrary, it is seen in scurvy.

Radiographic features of rickets:

  • Widening of the growth plate: Decreased calcification leads to reduced bone density
  • Fraying: The edge of the metaphysis loses its sharp border.
  • Cupping: The edge of the metaphysis changes from a convex or flat surface to a more concave surface.
  • Splaying: Weight-bearing and stress on the uncalcified bone gives rise to the widening of the metaphyseal end.
  • Enlargement of the wrists and ankles due to the widening of the distal end of the metaphysis.
  • Coarse trabeculation of the diaphysis
  • Generalized rarefaction

questions.text: A 2-year-old child from an urban slum is diagnosed with nutritional rickets. Which of the following biochemical markers can be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
In nutritional rickets serum, alkaline phosphatase levels are increased.

Biochemical findings in nutritional rickets (nutritional vitamin D deficiency):

  1. Normal or low calcium (since due to low calcium and vitamin D deficiency, PTH increases which will try to normalize the low calcium)
  2. Parathyroid hormone levels are elevated (in order to increase the serum calcium)
  3. Hypophosphatemia (because of increased parathyroid hormone [PTH])
  4. Metabolic acidosis (secondary to PTH induced renal bicarbonate wasting)

questions.text: A child in your unit is admitted with alopecia, oligodontia, and features of rickets with elevated serum levels of alkaline phosphatase activity and 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D. What could be the pathology?
questions.solution:
Alopecia and oligodontia (reduced number of teeth) with features of rickets in a child is classically seen in vitamin D-dependant rickets type 2 where the pathology is end-organ resistance (receptor hyposensitivity) to vitamin D.

Rickets causes

  • Nutritional vitamin D deficiency
  • Secondary vitamin D deficiency
    • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 1 (defect in 1-alpha hydroxylase)
    • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 2 (end organ resistance)
    • Chronic kidney disease
  • Hypophosphatemic rickets
    • X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (PHEX gene mutation)
    • Autosomal dominant (fibroblast growth factor [FGF] resistance to endopeptidases)
    • Oncogenous rickets (increased FGF 23)

Note:

Vitamin D antibodies are found in most patients of systemic sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Vitamin D activation and Rickets

questions.text: Stoss therapy is used in the treatment of which of the following micronutrient deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Stoss therapy is used in the treatment of vitamin D deficiency.

There are 2 strategies for the administration of vitamin D:

  • Stoss therapy: Here, 300,000-600,000 IU of vitamin D are administered orally or intramuscularly as 2 or 4 doses over 1 day.

  • The alternative strategy is daily vitamin D with a minimum dose of 2,000 IU/day for a minimum of 3 months.

Both strategies should be followed by a daily vitamin D intake of 400 IU/day if the child is < 1-year-old or 600 IU/day if the child is >1-year-old. Children must also receive adequate dietary calcium and phosphorus.

questions.text: A child with rickets not responding to treatment is being evaluated. Investigations show serum calcium level of 9 mg/dL, low phosphate level of 2 mg/dL,  elevated alkaline phosphatase, and normal parathyroid hormone levels with normal arterial blood gas levels. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a child with a history of treatment-resistant rickets, normal levels of calcium (9 to 11 mg/dL), parathyroid hormone, arterial blood gas (ABG), with decreased phosphate (normal, 2.5 to 4.3 mg/dL), and elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase (normal, 33 to 96 U/L) is suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets.

Hypophosphatemic rickets:

X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common genetic cause of rickets while the most common, overall is nutritional vitamin D deficiency. PHEX gene (phosphate-regulating endopeptidase on x chromosome) products are responsible for the inactivation of phosphatonin. Mutation of this PHEX leads to increased phosphatonin (FGF 23) levels, and hence, the excretion of phosphorous is increased. This is also associated with impaired renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate leading to its excess excretion.

The chart attached below summarizes the evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Treatment-resistant rickets :

Patients respond well to a combination of oral phosphorus and 1,25-D (calcitriol). Frequent dosing helps prevent prolonged decrements in serum phosphorus levels because there is a rapid decline after each dose. In addition, frequent dosing decreases diarrhea, which is a complication of high-dose oral phosphorus.

  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

questions.text: A concerned mother of an infant, known case of cystic fibrosis, presents to your OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, loose stools not settling with antibiotics, and other medications. She recently stopped breastfeeding and switched to formula feeds. On examination, you find petechial rashes. Which of the following below mentioned causes would not prompt you to suspect a deficiency of Vitamin K in this child?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K deficiency occurs mostly in breastfed infants not in artificial milk-fed babies, as the formula milk is fortified.

The use of broad-spectrum antibiotics that eliminate the intestinal vitamin K2- producing bacteria can cause vitamin K deficiency. Biliary atresia causes malabsorption of vitamin K, due to defective fat absorption.

There are 3 forms of vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB) of the newborn:

  Secondary to maternal intake of medications Early VKDB (classic hemorrhagic disease of the newborn)  Late VKDB
Onset At birth 1 to 14 days 2 to 12 weeks
Cause Drugs that cross the placenta and interferes with Vit K function eg. phenobarbital, phenytoin, warfarin Low stores of Vitamin K at birth, poor transfer of Vitamin K across the placenta, Inadequate intake during the first few days of life.  In breastfed babies and in those with malabsorption of vitamin K (cystic fibrosis, biliary atresia)

Early VKBD of the newborn is prevented by the administration of a single intramuscular (IM) injection of vitamin K (1 mg) at birth.

questions.solution:
Bowing of legs is not a feature of rickets in infants, because it appears only after weight-bearing. Thus, bow legs are a feature of rickets in toddlers.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding phosphatonins?

choices.text: It increases the renal reabsorption of phosphate

questions.solution:
Phosphatonin is a group of phosphate-regulating factors produced by osteocytes, and FGF 23 is the most important phosphatonin. Phosphatonin increases renal excretion (not reabsorption) of phosphate.

Mechanism of phosphatonin action:

Vitamin D receptor activation by 1,25 dihydroxy D (active vit D)

                             ↓

FGF 23 release by osteocytes

                             ↓

Reduces expression of sodium-phosphate transporter in proximal convoluted tubules of the kidney

                             ↓

Increased urinary phosphate excretion

 

Meanwhile, phosphatonin decreases the activity of 1 alpha hydroxylase and, therefore, the production of 1,25-D as well. So, the absorption of phosphate from the intestine is also reduced.
